name: Kevin David
claims: Make $10,000/month selling on Amazon with no experience
Quit your 9-5 within 90 days
Follow my exact blueprint to financial freedom
reality: The Amazon FBA market is extremely saturated. Kevin's course teaches basics available free on YouTube. Most students report losing money on inventory and ads. His income primarily comes from course sales, not Amazon FBA.
redFlags: Rented Lamborghinis and mansions in ads
Income claims without proof or disclaimers
Aggressive upselling to higher-priced tiers
Fake urgency ('only 3 spots left')
Testimonials from other course sellers, not actual students
verdictDetail: Basic Amazon FBA info repackaged at massive markup. Most students lose money. Free YouTube tutorials teach the same content.

name: Tai Lopez
claims: Here in my garage, just bought this Lamborghini
Knowledge is the real asset — buy my course to learn
Build a million-dollar social media agency
reality: Tai Lopez is famous for flexing rented luxury items. His courses contain generic marketing advice. The 'Lamborghini in the garage' was later revealed to be rented. His wealth comes from course and ad revenue, not from the businesses he teaches.
redFlags: Flexing rented luxury items as proof of wealth
Vague promises of 'the good life'
67 Steps program is motivational fluff
Constant upselling and subscription traps
Claims expertise in dozens of unrelated fields
verdictDetail: The original fake guru. Rented Lambos, rented mansions, recycled motivational content. His real business is selling you the dream.

name: Dan Lok
claims: Make $10K-$100K/month as a high ticket closer
I went from broke immigrant to multimillionaire
My students are crushing it with this system
reality: Dan Lok's 'High Ticket Closer' program is essentially a sales training repackaged at extreme prices. Most graduates find it extremely difficult to find clients willing to pay the fees Dan promises. His wealth comes from course sales, not from closing deals for clients.
redFlags: Prices up to $49,997 for 'inner circle' access
Backstory of being a broke immigrant used as manipulation
Students pressured to sell his courses to others (MLM-like)
Fake scarcity and countdown timers
Most testimonials are from other course sellers
verdictDetail: Overpriced sales training with MLM-like student recruitment. Inner circle pricing is predatory. Free sales training on YouTube is better.

name: Sam Ovens
claims: Start a consulting business from scratch
Replace your 9-5 income in 6 months
Join 10,000+ successful graduates
reality: While Sam Ovens' course has more substance than most, the success rate is vastly overstated. The '10,000+ graduates' claim counts anyone who enrolled, not actual successes. The market for generic consulting is extremely competitive.
redFlags: Survivorship bias in testimonials
Success rate claims that count enrollment, not results
Upselling to more expensive programs
Webinar uses high-pressure tactics
Students primarily make money selling to other aspiring consultants
verdictDetail: Better than most guru courses but still overpriced. Success stories are cherry-picked. Realistic expectations are rarely set.

name: Iman Gadzhi
claims: Build a $10K/month agency as a teenager
Dropped out of school and made millions
Follow my exact framework
reality: Iman's course teaches SMMA (Social Media Marketing Agency) basics that are widely available for free. While he has built a real business, his income is primarily from courses, not client services. The market for SMMA is extremely saturated.
redFlags: Targets young people with dropout success story
Flexes lifestyle to sell the dream
SMMA market is massively oversaturated
Most value is available free on YouTube
Creates urgency with limited enrollment claims
verdictDetail: Legitimate content but massively overpriced for what you get. SMMA market is saturated. Free alternatives exist.

name: Andrew Tate
claims: Escape the Matrix
Learn crypto, copywriting, ecommerce, freelancing
Join a brotherhood of winners
reality: Despite the low price point, Hustlers University operates like an MLM. Members earn commissions for recruiting new members. The 'courses' are basic tutorials you can find free online. The Discord community is the main product, not the education.
redFlags: MLM-style affiliate recruitment is the core business model
Students incentivized to spam social media with recruitment
Course content is surface-level across too many topics
Cult-like community discourages criticism
Controversial figure using outrage for marketing
verdictDetail: MLM disguised as education. Members are the product, not the students. Affiliate recruitment is the real business model.

name: Grant Cardone
claims: 10X your income, your business, your life
I own $4 billion in real estate
Stop being average — invest in yourself
reality: Grant Cardone's real estate empire is heavily leveraged with debt. His courses teach aggressive sales tactics that many consider manipulative. The 10X conferences are primarily sales funnels for more expensive programs. Most of his wealth claims are based on gross asset values, not net worth.
redFlags: Wealth claims based on gross assets, not net worth
Aggressive high-pressure sales tactics taught and used
Conferences are expensive sales funnels
Real estate fund accessible only to accredited investors
Constant upselling to higher-priced programs
verdictDetail: Misleading wealth claims. Conferences are sales funnels. Teaches aggressive tactics many consider unethical.

name: Robert Kiyosaki
claims: Rich Dad Poor Dad — learn what the rich teach their kids
Financial education the schools don't teach
Build passive income through real estate
reality: While the original Rich Dad book has some valid principles, the seminar business is a licensed operation that has faced multiple lawsuits and complaints. The workshops use extreme upselling, pushing attendees into $45,000 mentorship programs using credit cards they're told to max out.
redFlags: Seminars encourage maxing out credit cards to pay for advanced programs
Licensed operators, not Kiyosaki himself, run most events
Multiple FTC complaints and lawsuits
Free seminar is a sales pitch for paid seminars
Company filed for bankruptcy in 2012
verdictDetail: The book is fine. The seminar business is predatory. They push you to max out credit cards for $45,000 programs run by licensees.

name: BitBoy Crypto (Ben Armstrong)
claims: My altcoin picks will 100x
I called the Bitcoin bottom
Join my inner circle for alpha calls
reality: BitBoy Crypto was exposed for promoting tokens he was paid to shill without disclosing the payments. He was fired from his own company after erratic behavior. His 'picks' often dumped after his audience bought in, a classic pump-and-dump pattern.
redFlags: Undisclosed paid promotions for tokens
Pump-and-dump pattern with recommended tokens
Fired from his own company for erratic behavior
Cherry-picks winning calls, ignores losses
Aggressive behavior toward critics
verdictDetail: Exposed for undisclosed paid crypto promotions. Pump-and-dump pattern. Fired from his own company. Do not trust his 'picks'.

name: Forex Signal Sellers
claims: Copy my trades and make $1,000/day
95% win rate on all signals
Financial freedom through forex trading
reality: The vast majority of forex signal services are scams. They show cherry-picked results, use demo accounts for screenshots, and make money from subscriptions — not trading. Studies show 70-80% of retail forex traders lose money. Signal sellers profit from subscriptions, not their own trading.
redFlags: Screenshots from demo accounts, not real money
Win rate claims that defy market reality
No verified track record on third-party platforms
Pressure to join quickly before 'price increases'
Revenue comes from subscriptions, not actual trading
Photoshopped profit screenshots
verdictDetail: Almost all forex signal services are scams. They make money from your subscription, not from trading. 70-80% of retail forex traders lose money.
